body:
Summarizing,
1. It would be great to know a way to dump IR to see whether all the intrinsic, device code and meta data are generated correctly (even data layout and target triple).
2. hipModuleLaunchKernel doesn't support the primary method from cudaLaunchKernel. It uses `extra_args`.
3. I am seeing a segfault when running 
```shell
$ python test_codegen_device.py
[23:11:18] src/runtime/rocm/rocm_module.cc:64: HSACO
Bus error (core dumped)
```
I have to debug on it more.

@tqchen I don't expect code to run as we have a new feature coming in from HIP (https://github.com/adityaatluri/HIP/commit/8a7328fd9de7f1d174e5f4b75de734fb4032f5b6). I'll write a CPP test to check whether the IR generated is valid or not. 
But, the purpose of this PR is to get good IR generated.

Can you elaborate a bit on what is expected? For example, is the problem lies in the additional argument packing, or other parts? We might be able to change the runtime accordingly to solve this issue

It would be nice to get a runnable code.

Specifically, we can pre-pack the arguments into a single buffer, if necessary, without going through the HIP CUDA compatible API.  

For example, in Metal runtime everything is packed into an array of ArgUnion, and the device code will r eceive a packed arguments instead https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/metal/metal_module.mm#L202

Now it could achieve comparable results as TF, even without the atomic. It would be great if it could have the atomic operator so that we could avoid the loop like this:  for (db.dh.dw.fused.fused.outer, 0, 17956). I will close the issue.
@Huyuwei @wetliu @Laurawly @icemelon9
It seems that #406 fixes this issue.

For now, in order to achieve the best performance on Raspberry PI, the TVM computation declaration and schedule is tightly coupled. For example, you need to choose which algorithm (spatial pack or im2col) to apply and the vectorization size by the workload. It is not good for the future extension and flexibility.

I think we need to introduce some data structures like `cudnnConvolutionDescriptor` in order to decouple them.

A good middle ground for now is to make schedule function generic, and dispatch to the specific schedule functions by tags, so user can always call the same schedule function regardless of which algorithm is chosen. It is good to have choices of algorithms, because it enriches the space we can work on
cc @ZihengJiang
got this issue when building directly using LLVM 6.0 on my local machine. How to fix it, thanks!
PLease use the latest code from master, which should already resolved this issue
@antinucleon
cc @Laurawly When doing rfactor, we need set_store_predicate so only store from one thread
This is intended, because in c++ the result is passed by ref (pointer), while in python they are directly returned

Thanks for the PR. Our goal in the tutorial is mainly on how to optimize kernel performance with tvm primitives, instead of directly calling into extern functions. So the current proposed tutorial is a bit off with the goal. Another thing is that pagerank usually uses sparse big matrices instead of small dense matrix.

A related topic would be computing recurrence of matrix exponential, which is related to rnn and that is actually an interesting topic. But again we want to focus more on how to achieve better performance with native tvm primitives

Try to use llvm's official binary repo. This does not seems to be a tvm issue. For quick fresh llvm installation. 

You can try https://apt.llvm.org/ or http://releases.llvm.org/download.html to get prebuild binary

The first warning has been fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/415 already, the second one is a false positive. Which does not occur in latest compilers, never-the less, i will submit a PR to suppress that
Thanks for reporting this. As the error message indicated, this seems to due to new restriction introduced by setup, should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/421
Thanks for reporting this, should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/421, for now you can try to use the makefile directly
thanks, will try.

In order to get a good autotuned kernels, there are two essential parts

- A large enough space of schedules to cover the state of art techniques in handcrafting kernels for various hardware backends (multi-core cpu, gpu etc)
- An auto tuner that can effectively explore the space.

The focus of the project so far has been on part one, because if the schedule space is not good enough,  we never get the comparable performance, however clever the tuner is.  A design of a good auto-tuner is also deeply tied with what is the candidate space of search and cost model to use.
This is one of the main problem we try to solve in tvm. There was a quite a a lot of heavy lifting to close in this gap and I think we are getting quite a lot lessons on what need to be done in here.

With the scripts API we have, it is pretty straight forward to get some quick auto-tuning scripts for the workloads we care, which is the techniques we use to get some of the optimized kernels. So in that sense we already are able to do auto tuning and get good results

A more principled auto tuner is on our roadmap. Also refer to http://docs.tvmlang.org/faq.html#tvm-s-relation-to-other-ir-dsl-projects  for relation with existing projects
cc @Huyuwei @icemelon9 @ZihengJiang
gives around 3x reduction in integration test time cost, 2x end to end test time for now
Thanks. I installed successfuly!

Would this be equivalent to (stride =2)

```
tvm.sum(A[k*2], k=tvm.reduce_axis((0, n/2))
```
/cc @psyhtest
Yes. It is equivalent to modify the compute in this way. Thank you!
Thanks, @tqchen , look forward to detailed plan for principled auto-tuner in the future.
Got it, thanks!
@tqchen I am able to see good IR now and be able to generate ISA from it (through llc). https://gist.github.com/adityaatluri/1ac1ff72b927e42fdd8a61f98176039a
Can you confirm the gap between this and actual kernel test that runs? Thanks
Can you explain a bit more about what you meant?
I mean directly run the test via the Rocm module and verify the correctness of the kernel

Gotcha. Turns out the IR is not valid. These lines are causing bad output results. https://gist.github.com/adityaatluri/1ac1ff72b927e42fdd8a61f98176039a#file-tvm-amdgcn-ll-L10
Do you know where they are coming from ?
Correct IR: https://gist.github.com/adityaatluri/1ac1ff72b927e42fdd8a61f98176039a#file-tvm-amdgcn-correct-ll

This is shift left, used for address calculation, in condition

```c++
if (blockIdx.x * 256 + threadIdx.x < n) { 
    ...
}
```
blockIdx.x * 256 becomes ```blockIdx << 8``` which corresponds to that line
Do you know which code block generate this?
Should due to LLVM's constant folder in IRBuilder, which automatically folds Mul(blockIdx, 256) into left shift, is the shift not supported by AMD ISA?
It does support shl/shr but I don't think we need to mul workitem id with 8. Also, I didn't see the last arg i32. Let me retest. Also, 1024 is good for AMDGPUs.
After retest, the data output got validated.
nice, can we directly use RocmModule to run the test instead of the current test that is de-coupled from the compiler?
We need new HIP which the team is working on. Once it lands, it'll make it easier to launch kernel.

I see what you mean by looking at the test code you provided. Actually the metadata is already available in TVMRuntime, and we are using this to pack the data. 

So one possible way is simply implement parameter packing in TVM. 

For example, https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/pack_args.h#L150 packs non pointer argument into a continuous memory region of one buffer(ArgUnion). This is used by Metal runtime, which requires non pointer arguments to be packed as one buffer. If we know the parameter packing requirement(e.g. alignment of each value)
What we need is to implement a PackFuncArg, similar to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/pack_args.h#L216 and gives us the packed pointer back to the callback
close this for now due to too long outstanding changes, please feel free to reopen once we have an updated version

please do more debugs, for example, use gdb to get back trace on where does the failure happens, also you can try print out the code of ocl and see if you can directly compile and run it on the local machine.
One quick thing to confirm is to check tvm.cl(0).exist
was due to a power outrage, it is now back online
@adityaatluri can you followup with the comments with argument packing and meta data in runtime? Thanks!
Yes. Can you review the codegen changes? Can you spin up CI build?

I have added two additional comments, the code now lgtm. The only thing we need to do is add parameter packing and do unittests. The CI machine was down due to power outrage and is back online again. The build should be triggered when you push next commit
cc @ZihengJiang @Laurawly
Examples in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/432/files#diff-92e5db064c4949635c76e1527e3452b1R176
It seems that test_schedule_cache_relayout4() is not added.

I found OpenCL of Intel(R) HD Graphics on my laptop is strange (not supported) :rofl: , OpenCL of Mali GPU on board is okay.

# Strange Intel(R) HD Graphics

local run:

```shell
In [1]: import tvm

In [2]: cpu = tvm.cpu(0)

In [3]: cpu.exist
Out[3]: True

In [4]: gpu = tvm.gpu(0)

In [5]: gpu.exist
Out[5]: False

In [6]: cl = tvm.cl(0)

In [7]: cl.exist
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
yuens@Spark:~/Software/tvm/python$ 
```

# Mali GPU is okay

Connection using RPC.

```shell
In [1]: import tvm

In [2]: from tvm.contrib import rpc, util

In [3]: server = rpc.Server(host='0.0.0.0', port=9090)

In [4]: remote = rpc.connect("192.168.1.56", 9090)

In [5]: cl = remote.cl(0)

In [6]: cl.device_id
Out[6]: 0

In [7]: cl.device_type
Out[7]: 132

In [8]: cl.warp_size
Out[8]: 1

In [9]: cl.max_threads_per_block
Out[9]: 256

In [10]: cl.exist
Out[10]: True

```
was due to stale build of doc, should be updated now
You need to use nose instead
specifically, do ```python -m nose```
It is weird. My machine can run the failed test. Is there any other information other than segmentation fault?
Unfortunately this is the only info, the build machine I believe is a g2
Thank you. I think that's the problem. I have changed the compute arch to 3.0 for g2.
Please do not use nvcc_compiler hook in the testcases, simply remove them and nvrtc will pick up
Got it. So in what case it will give incorrect answers?
seems the cuda schedule just happened to be fine, but it cannot generated ir correctly for default schedule
I see. Good to know it didn't break the cuda schedule. I haven't checked ir code before. Will do the checking for other schedules too.

of course, will do this weekend.

there is a restriction on typical vector lanes we can use currently the opencl generator is not that smart to break long vectors. So to vectorize with lane=4(for float) do a split with factor=4, and vectorize on inner dimension
You passed a local ctx to a remote cpu in creating and running of time evaluator , pass remote.cpu instead
:rofl:

This being said, that error message is confusing, let us change it to 

```
TVMRPC: Can not pass in local context or context with a different remote session
```
@ysh329 do you mint do a pass on the rpc related file and update the error message?
got, thanks

One thing to notice, I see warning

```
[17:56:20] src/schedule/message_passing.cc:252: use fallback inference rule in fuse
```

This happens when we are relying on a fused operator whose value need to be a range, but tvm cannot decide the storage needed for the fused operator, so it simply says i want everything to be computed. This can actually cause duplicated computations and may not be intended case, so we should consider remove it(by not fusing some axis).

@Huyuwei @wetliu
Thanks. And now there are some inconsistent test results going on; I am trying to figure out why.
It seems the error (at least on my local machine) of the inconsistent numerical results are due to the fact that the old memoize files. Can you remove them and let it run again? Thank you!
I see. I will do a clean
The old files are now removed. The build should be triggered if you push a new commit. Please look into the fuse issue and fix it if possible
It seems the warning @tqchen mentions is due to this test file: test_topi_conv2d_nchw.test_conv2d_nchw. @Huyuwei @Laurawly
Yeah, there's a sub function in conv2d_nchw with this warning which I haven't fixed yet because it turned out to have worse performance than not fusing. Will fix this today.
cc @ZihengJiang
will merge after @Huyuwei approve
Yuwei simplifies the backward wrt weight.
Thanks, this is merged

```python
evaluator = f.time_evaluator(func.entry_name, tvm.cpu(0), number = 1)
```
to
```python
evaluator = f.time_evaluator(f.entry_name, remote.cpu(0), number = 1)
```
